Sam Brenner.Action: Smiles at Will Cooper and invites him to join in on activities.
Accepts Will Cooper taking a jar of coins from the lemonade stand without objection.
Rides bike fast and crazed through the suburbs, indicating confidence and control.
Initiates plans by telling Cooper 'It’s open,' showing leadership and initiative.
Calmly observes the arcade with awe, demonstrating curiosity and engagement.
Explains game characters to Cooper patiently and kindly.
Studies others playing games to learn and improve.
Studies others playing Pac Man, analyzing their successes and failures before playing himself.
Immediately recognizes patterns in Pac Man movements without prior experience, demonstrating high game intuition and skill.
Plays multiple classic arcade games at a high level, indicating broad and competent skill.
Steps away from game to eat despite a respectful crowd watching, showing consideration for his needs.
Admits to Cooper that he sucks at school and sports but is good at video games, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Compliments Cooper on abilities like talking people into things and making up stories, demonstrating friendliness and encouragement.
Invites Ludlow to hang out with them after noticing he has no friends.
Initiates friendly interaction by inviting Ludlow to hang out with them, showing social confidence combined with awareness of others' skills.
Observes Ludlow playing and talking under his breath but does not ridicule or dismiss him, indicating social perceptiveness and emotional intelligence.
Does not show any hesitation or insecurity when encountering Eddie Plant and his aggressive taunts, suggesting calmness and confidence.
Plays BREAKOUT zen-cool as slo-mo Cooper cheers him on.
Shakes his head in response to Eddie Plant's 'choke' sign.
Wishes opponent good luck before the match.
Accepts defeat silently after losing to Eddie Plant.
Smiles confidently before the match and competes strongly against Eddie Plant, initially pulling ahead.
Loses focus and rubs his eyes when the game speeds up and the pattern is lost, leading to a comeback by Eddie.
Despite losing, shows he was capable of tying for world records in multiple games beforehand.
Greets homeowner politely despite feeling miserable and depressed.
Hates his life and shows signs of internal suffering but does not take it out on others.
Feels envy and longing when observing a happy family outside but does not express resentment or bitterness aloud.
Loses at the one thing he was great at, showing disappointment and devastation.
Performs his job installing a 70 inch 4K TV to the wall professionally, despite personal unhappiness.
Presents himself to the homeowner with low confidence and visible misery.
Startled by the third child and drops the TV, smashing it.
Responds calmly to the situation by asking for tape to fix the TV.
Advises Cooper to take time to focus on his wife by shutting off distractions.
Exhibits self-deprecation and doubt about his own abilities and career path.
Laughs at Cooper’s reading mistake in a friendly, teasing way.
Jokes about his own busy schedule but clearly engaged with Cooper’s reading.
Shows empathy toward Cooper being tired and forgetful.
Asks Secret Service agents to help Cooper by grabbing his wallet, expressing concern and frustration in a lighthearted manner.
Laughs confidently at President Cooper's poor reading skills and cracks a joke about it.
Remains aware of his schedule, mentioning his 2 o’clock install, indicating responsibility.
Asks the Secret Service agents to get the President’s wallet, showing practical problem-solving.
Shows disgust at the agents' failure to prevent the wallet mishap, implying expectations of competence from others.
Mocks President Cooper rather than offering direct help with the reading issue.
Admits to being called 'the Nerd' and accepts it with humor.
Engages in lighthearted banter with Matty, showing an approachable and friendly demeanor.
Shows empathy by acknowledging Matty's family troubles with a relatable, supportive comment.
Confidently owns the label 'Nerd' and uses humor to deflect potential negativity.
Asks a practical question about what he is installing, showing engagement and professionalism.
Engages empathetically in conversation about personal matters without losing composure.
Compliments Violet awkwardly and sincerely, showing vulnerability and making a friendly connection.
Embarrasses himself by awkwardly complimenting Violet and fumbling social interaction.
Attempts to regain composure quickly and shifts focus back to task by starting to set up equipment.
Engages in lighthearted teasing with Matty, laughs together, shares nostalgic stories about classic arcade games.
Responds to Matty’s blunt, somewhat dark humor with casual banter and a smile, indicating tolerance and friendliness.
Sets up the video game system with apparent ease and confidence.
Confidently explains classic arcade games to Matty, showing knowledge and skill.
Engages in casual banter with Matty without losing composure.
Makes no notable mistakes or signs of confusion during the setup or conversation.
Knocks on Violet’s door, communicates clearly and professionally about completing work and needing a signature, and displays social awareness by commenting on the awkwardness of calling her 'Mrs.'
Notices Violet crying in the closet, hesitates but then chooses to enter the closet to be with her.
Offers Violet a chance to talk and gently comforts her when she starts crying on his shoulder, awkwardly pats her back.
Comforts Violet by entering the closet despite awkwardness and offers emotional support when she is crying.
Momentarily unsure whether to leave or stay when hearing Violet sobbing, showing hesitation.
Sits with Violet sharing a drink and listens to her troubles, offering dark humor to help lighten the mood.
Suggests Violet take a deep breath and then go confront her ex and his new partner with humor and a bit of reckless flare.
Wipes Violet's tears away and shares a smile with her, showing comfort and empathy.
Attempts to comfort Violet by reframing her failed marriage as a step towards finding the right guy.
Leans in to kiss Violet during an emotionally vulnerable moment, despite her quick rejection.
Engages in light teasing with Violet about his weight and her being snobby, maintaining friendly banter.
Jokingly confronts Violet with a playful hypothetical about kissing on a yacht.
Abruptly ends the moment to take a phone call, prioritizing the call over the personal interaction.
Corrects Violet playfully and shows quick wit when she calls him a '210 pound dork' by saying 'First of all, 208.'
Leans in to kiss Violet impulsively in her closet without gauging her comfort, leading to an awkward rejection.
Maintains composure and humor throughout the conversation, demonstrating social ease and confidence.
Takes an important phone call immediately when the caller ID shows 'PRESIDENT CHEWIE,' indicating he is involved in significant matters.
Jokes teasingly with Violet about making out and being an amazing kisser.
Dismisses Violet abruptly and coldly, telling her 'It's over. Deal with it.'
Mentally labels Violet as 'psycho' after she chases him in her car.
Warns White House guard about Violet in a sarcastic, dismissive way.
Engages Cooper with concern and curiosity about the naval base attack, showing genuine interest in the situation.
Responds cockily to Violet's comment about importance, displaying a competitive side rather than friendliness.
Correctly identifies a strange sound from blurry footage and requests to zoom in for a closer look.
Displays confidence and a bit of cockiness by moonwalking into the Oval Office and teasing Violet about importance.
Appears momentarily flummoxed when greeted unexpectedly, showing slight confusion.
Makes a humorous comment to defuse tension during an intense discussion in the White House, referring to Admiral Porter's aggressive suggestion and addressing him playfully as 'Grandpa'.
Watches the tape of the attack repeatedly and pauses to study something closely.
Makes a sarcastic but insightful comment about the Defence Secretary possibly driving them into a ditch.
Appears casually dressed in bright orange shorts in a high-stress official meeting, which could be seen as unprofessional or lacking seriousness.
Responds with humor about making a blow dryer from simple materials.
Corrects others with detailed knowledge about the original Galaga game but uses mocking tone toward Violet’s comment.
Salutes and politely exits the tense meeting, shows respect to officials despite their dismissiveness.
Makes a joking comment to the Defense Secretary to lighten the mood.
Feels stupid and self-conscious after the meeting.
Responds to Ludlow’s sudden appearance with a backhand punch before recognizing him.
Acknowledges the President and military officials respectfully, salutes appropriately, and tries to maintain composure despite feeling out of place.
Tries to lighten the mood with a joke towards the Defense Secretary, showing social awareness and confidence.
Feels stupid and uncomfortable after the meeting, suggesting self-doubt or insecurity in a high-stress situation.
Reactively punches Ludlow upon recognizing him, almost causes an accident by slamming on brakes, showing impulsiveness and poor control.
Immediately reacts with physical violence by punching Ludlow when he is startled and scared.
Recognizes Ludlow after the initial confrontation and engages in conversation without escalating further.
Questions Ludlow about the suspicious bottle in a direct but not hostile manner.
Comments sarcastically about the imaginary character Lady Lisa being scared.
Recognizes a potential threat quickly and reacts decisively by hitting Ludlow to protect himself.
Immediately questions suspicious behavior, displays situational awareness by noticing Ludlow's chloroform and confronting him about it.
Assumes the van is safe when left unlocked in the White House parking lot, showing some naivety or overly trusting behavior.
Engages with Ludlow’s conspiracy-laden apartment and strange behavior without dismissing him outright, demonstrating open-mindedness and a certain level of social adaptability.
Sets aside the flipbook when Ludlow begins to remove his shirt, showing restraint and situational focus instead of being distracted.
Listens and engages with Ludlow's conspiracy theory conversation with light humor.
Makes a joke about 'ET phone home' and the ghost of Elvis during the conversation.
Acknowledges and recalls past shared experiences with Ludlow (Video Game Championship, orbiter tape).
Questions Ludlow's motivations and theories with a hint of skepticism and sarcasm (Oh no, here comes a theory; How does the ghost of Elvis fit into this?).
Engages in banter that shows quick wit (ET phone home), indicating mental agility and sound memory.
Does not directly challenge the dubious or conspiratorial content from Ludlow but rather responds with humor and mild skepticism, not pushing to clarify or correct misinformation.
Listens carefully and asks a clarifying question ('So what was?') when Ludlow shows unexpected VHS footage instead of the advertised show.
Jokingly threatens Ludlow with a playful, lighthearted remark.
Dismisses alien threat with sarcasm calling them morons.
Exchanges a knowing look with Ludlow indicating awareness of the seriousness despite others dismissing the threat.
Gives Violet a cocky look, smirking exchanged.
Teases Ludlow with 'Handle your high'
Gives President Cooper a cocky look and confidently navigates a high-security facility despite being a civilian.
Acts dismissively towards Ludlow's excitement, showing awareness and control over the situation.
Responds to Violet’s complex explanation with a sarcastic joke ('Wow, are you a robot too?') instead of engaging seriously with the scientific discussion.
Jokes teasingly with Violet about kissing her and the Mississippi Institute of Technology, showing playful familiarity.
Shows concern for Matty by bringing him along due to lack of a babysitter, indicating thoughtfulness and care.
Attempts to engage lighten the heavy atmosphere by speaking informally and humorously around serious military personnel.
Does not assert authority or command even when among elite Navy SEALs, defers to others like Admiral Porter.
Expresses casual interest and understanding about the prototype weapons and the pixel behavior.
Makes a sarcastic or inappropriate joke to Violet about how he got into the institute and personal regrets.
Nudges Violet to inquire about Matty's security clearance, showing awareness and responsibility.

Intervenes to stop Ludlow from provoking a SEAL aggressively.
Tells Ludlow to be confident and act the part, showing leadership and understanding of the situation.
Attempts to maintain control when Ludlow loses composure and insults the SEALs, indicating situational awareness and restraint.
Allows Ludlow to aggressively confront the SEALs, which escalates tension and could be seen as a failure to manage the situation effectively.
Steps in to protect Matty from being attacked by the SEAL.
Acknowledges and compliments the SEALs' real-world skills while humbly describing his own unique but limited abilities.
Uses humor and self-deprecation (‘civilian morons’, ‘drug parties’) to ease tension and connect with the troops.
Calmly tells Ludlow to let the matter go, diffusing potential conflict.
Steps in to prevent a violent confrontation calmly and confidently.
Addresses highly trained troops with humility but explains the unique skills he and Ludlow possess.
Uses humor and self-awareness effectively to gain rapport with military personnel.
Provides specific, actionable advice to a Navy SEAL struggling with a video game.
Allows Ludlow to take over a demonstration when appropriate, showing flexibility and team spirit.
Defuses conflict between Ludlow and others by telling Ludlow to 'let it go', demonstrating social awareness.

Yells tactical instructions to SEALS from behind the fence to help them succeed.
Attempts to share critical information about the attack pattern with the SEALS despite being stopped by the SAS officer.
Complies with the officer’s order and returns behind the barrier without further confrontation.
Identifies the pattern of the attacking aliens correctly as 'Centipede' and gives clear, strategic instructions to the SEALS on how to attack them effectively.
Quickly identifies the mistake Seals make by splitting the centipedes and instructs them to aim for the head only.
Reminds Seals to shoot the mushrooms first to prevent the centipedes from reaching the ground, showing his knowledge of the situation and the game mechanics.
Mutters distractedly about Violet's attractiveness during a critical battle moment.
Leaps over the barrier and shoves an officer to the ground to save a SEAL from the centipede, then takes control of the weapon and shoots the creature down.
Corrects others and instructs them to anticipate patterns in the attacking centipedes, showing confidence and willingness to help.
Encourages Ludlow despite his fear, telling him to hit the start button and expressing confidence.
Shoots the hopping spider to save Admiral Porter, and speaks in a friendly, casual way ('You're welcome, homeboy!').

Calmly takes aim and shoots a fast-moving hopping spider just in time to save Admiral Porter.
Relies on Ludlow to hit the start button but provides clear direction and moral support.
Runs after the Centipede to protect pedestrians and follows it into an apartment building
Shoots at the Centipede inside the apartment, but ends up destroying the old woman's TV, potentially disturbing her
Runs in hot pursuit of the remaining Centipede, following it despite chaotic surroundings.

Misses the target and accidentally destroys an old woman's TV.
Questions the Centipede with confusion and lacks clear strategy ('Why are you here? What do you want?!').
Shoots to save a little boy from the attacking centipede, preventing harm.

Raises a glass in honor of a fallen comrade during a celebration, showing respect and camaraderie.
Responds appreciatively and sincerely to Violet’s compliment.
Takes aim at the flying centipede and repeatedly shoots it until it is destroyed, saving a little boy.
Fires once and misses the centipede, blowing apart the TV instead.

Throws his tequila shot over his shoulder, demonstrating confidence and lighthearted skill in the drinking game.

Downplays his and his team's heroic efforts, calling the victory a fluke.
Reluctantly agrees that 'we might need him' despite clear personal discomfort.
Downplays the team's role despite their success, calling the victory a fluke and distancing himself from responsibility.

Shows situational awareness and strategic thinking by acknowledging they might need someone he does not want to see, indicating realistic judgment.

Responds calmly and confidently to the Police Commissioner’s inquiry about the situation.
Does not display hesitation or confusion when facing a new challenge in New York City.

Politely and confidently acknowledges the inventor of Pacman, showing social awareness and respect.

Welcomes Professor Iwatani aboard and takes charge by initiating work confidently despite nervousness, showing leadership and professional demeanor.
Struggles with strapping himself in but hides nervousness, allowing Violet to help, showing some vulnerability but still managing the situation.
Engages in light banter with Violet and teammates, demonstrating social ease and maintaining morale under pressure.
Confidently communicates with teammates over comms and directs roles lightly, showing command and situational awareness.
Expresses disbelief that Pac-Man could be a bad guy.

Recognizes Pacman's speed and immediately shifts into high gear to try to keep up.
Breaks off with Wonder Fro as part of a tactical plan to outmaneuver Pacman on Eddie Plant's orders.
Makes a casual, joking remark about the situation ("That was some crazy Pinocchio shiz-nit right there."), showing some lightness but not carelessness.
Moves into position to flank Pacman alongside teammates, cooperating in the plan.
Responds with a straightforward 'Nope' when stopping Pacman, showing no aggression or harshness.
Celebrates teamwork tacitly by saying 'One down!' after helping capture Pacman.
Notices the danger of the power pill quickly and yells out to warn others while taking immediate evasive action by shifting into reverse and flooring it.
After making a hard turn to evade Pacman, he loses sight of him, suggesting a momentary loss of control or situational awareness.
Encourages Eddie and acknowledges good work during the pursuit, remaining calm and focused.
Coordinates with teammates, strategically chasing Pacman alongside Eddie before letting Eddie speed ahead.
Smiles when seeing New Yorkers cheering him on, clearly moved by their support.
Sits in his car and hesitates instead of immediately pursuing the target, showing restraint and consideration.
Stops in the middle of the street, breathes heavily, feels pressure but then reassures himself 'I got this' and shifts into high gear to chase Pacman.

When seeing Pacman going towards the power pill, slams on brakes, prepares to reverse and flee, but then stops, thinks twice, turns the car around and sits there motionless, causing others to question his behavior.
Refuses to abandon his position despite danger, reassuring Violet that she will see her son grow up.
Continues to take extreme personal risks by staying in the car while being chased by Pacman, showing self-sacrifice.

Maintains calm and focus while counting down under extreme pressure, skillfully drives in reverse to evade Pacman, and times the jump perfectly so the car turns blue at the count of ten preventing capture.
Drives skillfully to win the game, eliciting cheers from the crowd.
Shakes hands amicably with rival Eddie Plant despite competition.
Executes a daring maneuver that leads to victory in the game, earning cheers and admiration from onlookers.
Receives praise from Eddie Plant, a skilled rival, acknowledging Brenner's impressive skills.
Calmly handles public attention and well-wishers after his success, showing confidence and composure.
Protects Q-Bert from harm, insists on keeping the creature safe and wants to play with it later.

Leads the group by being the first to climb the ladder quickly, showing initiative and urgency.

Aims his gun immediately at the approaching alien version of himself, showing alertness and readiness.
Refuses to hesitate or negotiate with the aliens, threatening to destroy the ship and all on it including himself, demonstrating firm decisiveness.

Calms others by suggesting a peaceful resolution with the aliens and asks them to turn off the Zorex to stop the attack.
Calmly negotiates peace with the aliens instead of escalating conflict.

Responds to Ludlow's disappointment with a straightforward but empathetic explanation
